author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

> Wouldn’t `MomentOptimization` be more descriptive?

There is a package MomentOpt. I would like to avoid the confusion with it.
Moreover, it contains tools to extract minimizers from moment sequences.

Is it the obstacle to see it as a registered package ?

[noblock]. It's just that "Tools" is an extremely non-descriptive word. I'd generally avoid it in package names, except maybe for packages that directly relate to a framework of packages (similar to how "Base" is used: you could have "Tools" for utilities shared by the packages in a specific organization).

So `MomentTools` doesn't really give much of an indication of what this package is about. My suggestion was based on the sentence in the README "This a Julia package for solving polynomial optimization problems, via moment matrix relaxations".

> There is a package MomentOpt

So then how does this package compare to that package? That might be something to mention in the README, and something to take into account when choosing a more descriptive package name.
I will rename the package MomentPolynomialOpt.jl (which is longer but more descriptive since tools for Moment and Polynomial Optimization are provided by the package) and hope it can be registered.

body:
